JournalInfo.JournalSubTitle: Zeitschrift für Rohstoffe, Geotechnik, Metallurgie, Werkstoffe, Maschinen- und Anlagentechnik

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Effect of Aqua Blasting, Sandblasting and Laser Engraving on the Corrosion Resistance of Type 316 Stainless Steel
Einfluss von Wasserstrahlen, Sandstrahlen und Lasergravieren auf die Korrosionseigenschaften von 316L Edelstahl

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Corrosion & Protection Centre, School of Materials

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The goal of this paper is to advance our understanding about the influence of commercial surface finishing treatments on microstructure development and corrosion resistance of a type 316L stainless steel. Aqua blasting, sandblasting, and application of a laser barcode engraving treatment were investigated using Focus Ion Beam, X-ray phase analysis, X-ray residual stress measurements, and surface roughness measurements. All surface microstructures were then assessed with atmospheric corrosion tests at 50 °C and 30 % relative humidity. Aqua blasting resulted in compressive surface residual stresses of − 500 to − 600 MPa, with no evidence of strain-induced martensite. Sandblasting led to compressive surface residual stresses of − 700 MPa, also with no evidence of strain-induced martensite. The samples subjected to laser engraving exhibited a recrystallized near-surface microstructure, with tensile surface residual stresses in the order of + 500 MPa.

Atmospheric corrosion tests were carried out using MgCl2 concentrations of 38–772 µg/cm2, with optical and laser confocal microscopy applied to quantify the development of corrosion products over time. The latter was correlated with the maximum depth of attack after exposure for 370 days of exposure. Atmospheric corrosion tests with deposition densities exceeding 38 µg/cm2 MgCl2 led to the formation of corrosion products within the first 24 hours of exposure, with the development of corrosion products following parabolic growth laws. It is further shown that higher deposition densities led to fewer localised corrosion sites, but with larger dimensions in size. Laser engraving resulted in a higher number corrosion sites compared to the aqua blasted surfaces, with MgCl2 deposited over the interface between both finishing treatments indicating preferential attack on the laser engraved microstructure.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: Die Veröffentlichung hat das Ziel, über den Einfluss von kommerziell erhältlichen Oberflächenbehandlungen und deren Auswirkung auf die Mikrostruktur und Korrosionseigenschaften zu informieren. Der Einfluss auf die Mikrostruktur wurde mit Focus Ion Beam Messungen, Röntgenbeugungsanalyse, Eigenspannungsmessungen und Rauhigkeitsmessungen bestimmt. Atmosphärische Korrosionsuntersuchungen wurden bei 50 °C und 30 % relativer Luftfeuchtigkeit an allen Oberflächenzuständen durchgeführt.

Wasser- und Sandstrahlen führen zu Druckeigenspannungen in der Größenordnung von − 500 bis − 700 MPa ohne den Nachweis von Verformungsmartensit. Ein anschließendes Lasergravieren auf den gestrahlten Proben führt zur Rekristallisation der oberflächennahen Region in Kombination mit Zugspannungen (+ 500 MPa).

Die mechanisch behandelten Proben wurden über 388 Tage mit aufgebrachten MgCl2 Tropfen ausgelagert. Die applizierten Korrosionstropfen führten zu MgCl2 Konzentrationen zwischen 38–772 µg/cm2. Die Veränderung der Korrosionsprodukte über den Auslagerungszeitraum wurde mittels Licht- und Konfokalmikroskop quantifiziert und anschließend mit der maximalen Korrosionstiefe korreliert. Die atmosphärischen Korrosionsuntersuchungen zeigten für MgCl2 Konzentrationen größer als 38 µg/cm2 die Formation von Korrosionsprodukten innerhalb der ersten 24 Stunden. Die Entwicklung der Korrosionsprodukte folgt dem parabolischen Wachstumsgesetz. Des Weiteren hat sich gezeigt, dass mit steigender Tropfenkonzentration die Anzahl der Korrosionsstellen zurückgeht, aber das Volumen und die Korrosionstiefe zunehmen. Die lasergravierten Oberflächen zeigten sich im Vergleich zu wassergestrahlten Oberflächen anfälliger. Das äußert sich in einer größeren Anzahl von Korrosionsstellen und in dem bevorzugten Angriff der lasergravierten Oberflächen in einem System, in dem beide Oberflächenbehandlungen demselben korrosivem Medium ausgesetzt sind.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The influence of commercial surface finishing treatments on microstructure development and corrosion performance is still subject for research. Optimisation of microstructure corrosion performance has been focused on either controlling bulk material properties by thermo-mechanical processing, changing the near-surface microstructure using surface treatment techniques, or through application of coating systems [1–3]. For example, surface finishing treatments have been reported to improve pitting corrosion resistance with the application of sandblasting and wire brushing [4]. A positive effect on the pitting corrosion resistance was also noticed for laser and shot peened surfaces [5]. Other work [6], however, indicated a reduction in corrosion resistance with increasing surface roughness after shot peening or sandblasting, due to the formation of local micro-crevices. Surface finishing treatments have a significant influence on localised corrosion behaviour, with “rougher” surfaces typically associated with an increase in the passive current density and higher pit nucleation propensities [7, 8].

Far less attention has been paid so far to understand the influence of laser engraving (e.g. for barcode labels) on the corrosion resistance after shot peening or sandblasting. The effect of femto-second laser markings on martensitic and type 316L austenitic stainless steel showed for both materials an improvement of the pitting corrosion resistance [9]. This work aims to provide an understanding of the influence of commercial surface finishing treatments on microstructure development and corrosion susceptibility of type 316L stainless steel.

Section1.Heading: Material and Methods
Section1.Para: A mill annealed, as-received type 316L austenitic stainless steel sheet with a chemical composition of (wt.%) 16.7 Cr, 10.1 Ni, 2.04 Mo, 0.019 C, and 0.049 N was used in this study. The mill annealed material condition is used as reference in this work. The sheet had a dimension of 1000 mm × 1000 mm × 1 mm (L × W × T) from which stripes with dimensions of 500 mm × 30 mm × 1 mm (L × W × T) were cut for further processing.

Optical micrographs of the as-received microstructure condition were obtained using a Carl Zeiss Axio Scope A1 Light Microscope with an AxioCam ERc 5s camera. To reveal the microstructure, the specimens were etched in 10 wt.% oxalic acid at room temperature with an applied potential of 4 V for up to 60 seconds.

EBSD analysis of the as-received sample was carried out using a FEI Quanta 650 field emission gun scanning electron microscope (FEG-SEM), equipped with HKL Nordlys EBSD detector using Aztec Version 2.2 for data acquisition. The accelerating voltage was set to 20 kV, with a step size to 1.274 μm over an area of 383 × 284 μm. The recorded data was processed with Channel 5 software. EBSD assessment was carried out to inform about the as-received microstructure condition of the type 316L stainless steel sheet. Low-angle grain boundaries (LAGB) were determined with a mis-orientation between 2° and 15°.

A batch of samples was aqua blasted by using 60/80mesh grit mixed in a weight ratio of 2:1 with water. A corrosion inhibitor was added to prevent corrosion attack during the aqua blasting treatment. Afterwards all samples were immersed in cold water, rinsed and dried in air to remove any remaining abrasive media. Abrasive sandblasting was manually carried out with 13 grit silica sand using 8 bar pressure and a working distance between 5 and 10 cm. Laser engraving in the form of barcode stripes produced on aqua blasted surfaces were also investigated.

The development of the surface microstructure of the as-received, aqua blasted and sandblasted material was studied using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis with Co-Kα radiation (λ = 1.78901 Å). A Philips X’Pert-1 diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Bragg-Brentano geometry was used with the following parameters: 40 kV, 40 mA, scan step size of 0.05 [°2θ], 4 seconds exposure for each data point. The laser engraved material was analyzed using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) on the Philips X’Pert Modular Powder diffractometer (Bragg-Brentano geometry and graphite monochromator) using the same parameters as above.

Surface residual stresses were determined using the sin2ψ method with a Proto X-ray diffractometer equipped with Mn Kα (λ = 2.1031 Å) to study the in-plane stresses of the {3 1 1}-plane. The measurements were carried out for 11 angles of ± 27° with 3° beta-oscillation using a 1 mm diameter aperture. Two sample orientations (ϕ) were measured with (ϕ= 0°) along the length (L) of the sheet, and (ϕ= 90°) along the width (W).

The surface topography and depth of attack of all samples was analysed with a Keyence VK-X200K 3D Laser Scanning Microscope at 200-times magnification using 0.1 μm z-step size and super fine resolution (2048 × 1536 pixels). This assessment provided information about the change of surface morphology as a function of surface finishing treatment and chloride concentration.

Section2.Heading: Microstructural Characterisation
Section2.Para: The microstructure of the as-received stainless steel sheet is shown in Figure 1a, with an average grain size of 22 ± 5 μm. EBSD analysis revealed the presence of 7–8 % LAGB’s and 37 % twin boundaries by length, shown in Figure 1b, showing an annealed austenitic microstructure. X-ray phase analysis revealed a small fraction of delta ferrite in the as received microstructure (Figure 2). The aqua blasted, sandblasted as well as laser engraved specimens only had the characteristic austenitic peaks ((111)γ, (200)γ, (220)γ, (311)γ, and (222)γ) with no evidence of ferrite or martensite (Figure 2).

Figure 3a shows the near-surface region of the aqua blasted specimen, Figure 3c the sandblasted specimen, both indicating a distinctive grain-refined and deformed layer (red bar). Laser engraving changed of the aqua blasted surface resulted in a different microstructure appearance, suggesting a recrystallized near-surface microstructure (arrow in Figure 3b).

CaptionContent.SimplePara: (a) Microstructure of as-received specimen etched with V2A-etchant. (b) EBSD map showing grain boundaries (black) and twin boundaries (red). The grey shading gives grain orientations contrast

X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-received (black) aqua (blue) and sandblasted (red) surface between 40 and 125 [°2Th.] using Co K-α. In the top right corner is the XRD pattern of the laser engraved surface (green) measured between 30 and 100 [°2Th.] using Cu K-α

(a) FIB cross-section of (a) an aqua blasted surface showing the deformation layer, (b) a laser engraved surface indicating possible recrystallized grains (red arrow), and (c) a sandblasted surface indicating the typical deformation layer

Section2.Heading: Surface Residual Stresses
Section2.Para: A representative lattice spacing (d) versus sin2ψ plot of the aqua blasted condition is shown in Figure 4a indicating a linear trend. Similar trends have been obtained for sandblasted and laser engraved specimens, supporting the assumption of a biaxial stress state and therefore strain can be determined using the sin2ψ method [10–11].

An overview of the measured residual stresses of all specimens is given in Figure 4b. In the as-received specimen of maximum ~ 70 MPa, with a standard deviation of ~38 MPa were measured, which is close to typical variations obtained with this technique. The aqua and sandblasted specimens respectively contain compressive surface stresses of the order of − 500 MPa and − 700 MPa for both in plane directions (ϕ= 0°; ϕ=90°). This is linked to the expected presence of a near surface deformation layer caused by blasting and peening treatments [4, 12–15]. The presence of compressive surface residual stresses typically has a beneficial effect on the fatigue and stress corrosion performance [4, 16]. Laser engraving lead to highly tensile stresses (500 to 600 MPa) due to recrystallization of the deformed surface layer. Overall, the measured compressive stresses should provide a good resistance against stress corrosion cracking, while the tensile typically make the materials more prone towards stress corrosion cracking [17].

CaptionContent.SimplePara: (a) Typical lattice spacing (d) vs. sin2ψ plot of the aqua blast condition. (b) In plane surface residual stresses for as-received, aqua blasted, sandblasted, and laser engraved surfaces

Section2.Heading: Corrosion
Section2.Para: Figure 5a represents the corroded area as a function of exposure time for the laser engraved specimens. The formation of the corrosion layer seems to stagnate for 38 µg/cm2 at a coverage of ~ 25 %, whereas the other deposition densities led to increased areas.

Aqua blasted surfaces (Figure 5b) showed an increased percentage of corroded area reaching up to 50 % for 38 µg/cm2, 87 % for 386 µg/cm2, and 71 % for 772 µg/cm2 following the parabolic growth low. The difference of the corroded area between the laser engraved and aqua blasted is possibly linked to the surface morphology, especially for the laser engraved specimens. The optical images indicate that the corrosion products on laser engraved specimens follow the morphology of the engraved troughs. The surface roughness of the laser engraved surface was determined with Rz 25 µm, whereas the aqua blasted surface indicated a roughness typical for peened surfaces of Rz 16 µm. Besides the different surface roughness, a topography analysis of the barcode labels also indicated that the laser engraved lines are at least standing proud 5 µm over the bottom of the engraved area. This suggests that the barcode lines inhibited lateral corrosion expansion. Therefore, most of the observed corrosion product expansion was found spread along laser engraved labels.

The depth and distribution of corrosion attack beneath the observed corrosion (rust) layer was analyzed after 370 days of exposure. The specimens were cleaned using 10 wt.% citric acid at 60–70 °C for 24–48 hours, and the exposed surface characterized with the Keyence Laser Scanning Microscope. The number of pits within the corroded area showed MgCl2 concentration dependencies. On laser engraved specimens with 772 µg/cm2 MgCl2 on average five discrete corrosion sites, and on the aqua blasted specimens on average six sites were found, with the number of corrosion sites increasing by 50 % for laser engraved, and by 15 % for aqua blasted specimens with decreasing MgCl2 concentrations. The number of discrete localised corrosion sites was smaller at higher concentrations, but the actual size of each site was significantly lager compared to the corrosion sites at lower concentrations, shown in Figure 6.

Figure 6 also shows the surface topography of two aqua blasted specimens with laser engraved barcode labels, where MgCl2 droplets were applied at the interface to determine which surface treatment is more susceptible towards localised corrosion. An optical image in the bottom left corner in Figure 6a represents the corroded area (before cleaning), while the red circles identify the location of the localised corrosion attack. It was noted that all droplets resulted in corrosion on laser engraved areas, with 83 % of the droplets leading exclusively to corrosion on the laser engraved area, and 17 % also to significant corrosion sites on the aqua blasted area. The highest MgCl2 concentration (772 µg/cm2) led in average to ~ 1.5 corrosion sites, with the lower concentration (386 µg/cm2) resulting in an excess of 6 sites, but far smaller surface coverage. Laser engraving leads to a more susceptible surface condition compared to aqua blasting. A comparison between these two conditions and the type 316L as-received (1200grit) material condition is currently in progress.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: (a) Evolution of the corroded area as a function of MgCl2 deposition density on laser engraved surface. (b) Evolution of the corroded area as a function of MgCl2 deposition density on aqua blasted surface

Surface topographies taken with 200x magnification at the interface between the aqua blasted and laser engraved area (indicated by arrows), after 370 days the presence of localised corrosion attack was observed. (a) The bottom left image is an optical image showing the corroded area after 168 days with the red circle marking the spot of localised corrosion attack. (b) Localised corrosion attack of the exposed area caused by 386 µg/cm2 MgCl2

ItemContent.Para: Aqua and sandblasting introduced compressive residual stresses and a deformed layer, whereas laser engraving led to a recrystallized near-surface microstructure in combination with residual tensile stresses.
Atmospheric corrosion tests indicated corrosion product development within 24 hours of MgCl2 exposure with concentrations in excess of 38 µg/cm2.
The development of the corroded surface area showed parabolic behaviour, with the largest corrosion product development during the first week.
Laser engraved surfaces (barcode labels) were more susceptible for localised corrosion attack compared to aqua blasted specimens.
